awd_titl_txt: Growing into Teacher-Researchers: Using Mindsets to Frame Research for Noyce Scholars and PIs as a Component of Teacher Preparation
awd_abstract_narration:
As STEM professionals, STEM teachers need to continue to grow their content knowledge and research skill set.  Research experiences for undergraduates and for teachers have been shown to advance understanding of the nature of STEM disciplines, the processes of scientific research, and to assist in retention within the STEM disciplines and within the STEM teaching field.  Moreover, STEM teachers who participate in research experiences are better prepared to incorporate the professional practices of scientists, engineers, and mathematicians in their classrooms, impacting positively several thousands of precollege students.  This project, supported by the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, will leverage the STEM Teacher and Researcher Program (STAR), led by California Polytechnic State University, to place a cohort of thirty-two (total of 64) Noyce Scholars in immersive, mentored summer research experiences at national laboratories, universities, and research & development centers, in the Summer 2018 and 2019, respectively.  The Noyce Scholars will join other STAR Fellows as they work with researchers in conducting original research while also participating in concurrent workshops.  One type of workshop is designed to assist the Noyce STAR Fellows in incorporating the practices of working scientists, engineers, and mathematicians into their classroom teaching.  A second project-specific workshop will provide Noyce STAR Fellows with opportunities to become familiar with educational research results on mindsets about intelligence and belonging.  The Fellows will examine research on how perspectives of whether intelligence is innate or malleable can impact the ways in which individuals deal with personal and academic challenges, as well as how such views may help or obstruct whether or not they feel they belong in STEM disciplines.  The project will also test the effectiveness of strategies and tools in helping teacher-researchers interpret their own struggles in research in terms of healthy mindsets for intelligence and deepen their sense of belonging in STEM.  Results from this investigation will help to inform improvements in teacher-researcher programs and their role in teacher preparation efforts.  

In addition to providing Noyce Scholars with research experiences in research laboratories and professional development workshops, this project will conduct an educational research study focused on three research questions. First: What are STAR Fellows' prior implicit beliefs about intelligence, including their own and that of their students? Second: To what extent does framing summer STAR workshops with the view that belonging in the research community is largely determined by effort, as opposed to achievement, ameliorate Fellows' sense of unproductive struggle during the summer research experience? Third: To what extent does framing summer STAR workshops with the view that intelligence is malleable change the types of feedback that Fellows would provide struggling students? Researchers have documented that problematic teacher beliefs have a negative impact on their pedagogical choices.  This project's proposed research on beliefs about intelligence and belonging in STEM for this population of students in the teacher professional continuum will contribute to the knowledge base on research experiences for teachers. In addition, it will inform the design, implementation, and evaluation of more effective research immersion programs for teachers and students.  Attention to conceptual understanding is inadequate by itself to stem the tide of underrepresentation in STEM.  Non-cognitive issues in STEM learning and belonging, especially in the context of research experiences, have not been addressed by educational research to the depth they deserve. This project will contribute to filling this gap in the research literature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The STEM Teacher and Researcher (STAR) program is a national initiative that provides immersive 8- to 10-week summer research experiences to prospective STEM teachers from any California State University (CSU) campus and to Robert Noyce scholarship recipients affiliated with any institution in the nation. Since its inception in 2007 and through the end of Summer 2023, STAR will have served 630 aspiring and early career educatoprs (more than half a percent of all 100Kin10 teachers) in 881 research placements at more than 40 cooperating research settings (including national labs funded by NSF, NASA, DoE, DoD, NOAA, and USGS, as well as university laboratories and R&D settings). Successful STAR applicants have come from all 22 CSU campuses with teacher education programs and 88 Noyce programs throughout the United States, ultimately affecting more than 200,000 K-12 students. In addition to their summer research experience, STAR Fellows participate in weekly STEM Education Workshops facilitated by groups of experienced teacher educators, who help STAR Fellows translate their experience (and discomfort) in the lab into rich, authentic classroom inquiry-based practices. The multi-faceted workshops foster stances that are informed by research that has shown that productive struggle is an indispensable part of STEM learning for adults and K-12 students alike, support novice teachers in developing sophisticated mindsets about STEM, and mitigate the effects of social threats to STEM belonging. Each weekly, 3- to 5-hour educational workshop session includes opportunities to develop Fellows' deep understanding of growth mindsets and belonging. For example, Fellows work on a challenging math problem that necessitates productive struggle and then discuss their responses to that experience. Fellows also discuss their work in their research lab and focus on the shared experience of struggling within STEM disciplines and through the process of conducting research. These conversations are intended to normalize their experiences of challenge and help establish the universality of feeling confused or unsure in science as a feature of authentic learning. Research has shown that when hard work and struggle is conveyed as a normal process of academic work, feelings of belonging in the discipline are boosted. The STAR experience culminates in an annual conference, which includes several other programs that provide research experiences for teachers. This additional community-building experience affords STAR Fellows with opportunities to learn with, network, and be inspired by professionals at different stages in the teacher-researcher trajectory. 

Through this project, we studied the impact of participation in STAR on our Fellows' mindsets, perceptions of science, belonging, and endorsement of effective pedagogical practices. Data were collected at the beginning of the summer research placement ("pre summer"), at the end of it ("post summer"), and five months later, at the end of the annual conference. Results showed that participation in STAR led to a significant increase in Fellows' growth mindsets from pre- to post-summer experience, and from pre summer to the time of the conference. In addition, we found no significant decreases in growth mindsets from post summer to the time of the conference. Taken together, these results suggest that STAR is an effective and enduring intervention to foster growth mindsets in STEM teachers, even during the academic year, when they are not actively being engaged in ongoing professional development around the concepts of growth mindsets. In addition, STAR Fellows reported a significantly greater sense of belonging to the STEM community from pre summer to post summer. These gains in feelings of belonging, however, decreased by the time of the conference, suggesting a need for ongoing support of our Fellows in this area, after leaving the research experience. Lastly, Fellows reported an increase in intentional strategies to support their own students' use of effort. Pre to post summer, Fellows reported wanting to use fewer well-intentioned but ultimately disempowering comfort strategies (e.g., non-specific praising of students, telling them they had more opportunities to succeed in other courses (but not in STEM)) and wanting to use more effort strategies (e.g., telling students they would do better if they put in more focused effort). Fellows' open-ended responses also showed a shift from pre to post summer from being afraid to make students feel bad about their performance to more constructive in how they wanted to encourage students to put in more strategic effort.
